steps.title: Your CS Degree
steps.narration: Your CS degree gave you something powerful: the ability to think computationally. Algorithms, data structures, theory of computation‚Äîthese are timeless fundamentals that never go out of style.

steps.title: The Hidden Gap
steps.narration: But here's the truth nobody tells you: your degree taught you to think, not to ship. Academic programs focus on clean, isolated problems. Industry throws you into messy, evolving systems.

steps.title: Academic World
steps.narration: In school, you had clear specs, solo projects, and problems with known solutions. You implemented hash maps from scratch and analyzed sorting algorithms. The problems were hard but well-defined.

steps.title: Industry Reality
steps.narration: In industry, you inherit legacy code with technical debt. Requirements change mid-sprint. You debug across distributed systems. You collaborate with teams who have different opinions. The problems are ambiguous.

steps.title: This Is Your Bridge
steps.narration: This course is your bridge. We don't replace your fundamentals‚Äîwe translate them. You'll learn how theory becomes practice, how algorithms become systems, and how to ship code that actually runs in production.

steps.title: Your Solid Foundation
steps.narration: Good news: you already have the foundation. Every concept you learned in school has a direct counterpart in industry. The challenge is learning to see the connections.

steps.title: Data Structures ‚Üí Databases
steps.narration: Arrays, trees, and graphs become database schemas, indexes, and caching strategies. Your understanding of hash maps helps you design efficient queries. The principles transfer directly.

steps.title: OOP ‚Üí System Architecture
steps.narration: Encapsulation and inheritance scale up to services, APIs, and contracts. A microservice is just encapsulation at the network level. The patterns you learned apply at every scale.

steps.title: Algorithms ‚Üí Performance
steps.narration: Your algorithm analysis skills become performance optimization. You'll profile production systems, identify bottlenecks, and make scaling decisions. Big-O still matters‚Äîjust in new contexts.

steps.title: Networking ‚Üí API Design
steps.narration: TCP/IP and protocols become REST, GraphQL, and gRPC. Understanding how the network actually works gives you superpowers when designing and debugging APIs.

steps.title: Industry Ready
steps.narration: By the end of this course, you'll see the connections clearly. Your academic knowledge becomes your competitive advantage. You don't just code‚Äîyou understand why things work.

steps.title: Perfect Timing
steps.narration: You're entering the industry at the perfect moment. AI tools let you punch above your experience level from day one. This is a superpower previous generations didn't have.

steps.title: Understand Faster
steps.narration: Use AI to explain legacy code, map system architecture, and trace data flows. Before asking teammates, get AI to help you understand. You'll ask smarter questions and ramp up faster.

steps.title: Build Smarter
steps.narration: AI generates boilerplate, implements patterns, and writes tests. You focus on design decisions and architecture‚Äîthe parts that require human judgment. Work at a higher level of abstraction.

steps.title: Learn Continuously
steps.narration: AI explains concepts, finds best practices, and reviews your code. It's like having a senior engineer available 24/7 to answer questions and provide feedback.

steps.title: Communicate Better
steps.narration: Draft documentation, prepare for meetings, write clear PRs. Communication is half the job, and AI helps you express technical concepts clearly and professionally.

steps.title: Your Competitive Edge
steps.narration: Combined with your CS fundamentals, AI makes you formidable. You understand the theory AND you can execute at speed. This course teaches you to wield both together. Let's cross the bridge!

questions.question: What's the main gap between academic and industry coding?
options: Industry uses harder programming languages
Academic problems are easier
Industry requires working with ambiguity, legacy code, and teams
Industry pays more so the work is harder
questions.explanation: Industry work involves unclear requirements, inherited codebases, and collaboration‚Äîchallenges that clean academic problems don't prepare you for directly.

questions.question: Why is your CS degree still valuable in industry?
options: It's required to get past HR
It taught you fundamentals that translate to production skills
Companies need people who can implement sorting algorithms
It proves you can follow instructions
questions.explanation: Your CS fundamentals‚Äîalgorithms, data structures, computational thinking‚Äîdirectly translate to industry skills. You understand WHY things work, not just HOW.

questions.question: What does 'taught to think, not to ship' mean?
options: Academic programs don't teach anything useful
Industry doesn't value thinking
School focuses on understanding concepts, not deploying production systems
You need to think less and ship more
questions.explanation: Academic programs prioritize deep understanding of concepts. Industry requires taking that understanding and building reliable systems that serve real users at scale.

questions.question: How do data structures translate to industry skills?
options: They don't‚Äîindustry uses databases instead
You'll implement red-black trees in production
Understanding hash maps helps you design efficient database queries
Data structures are only for interviews
questions.explanation: Your knowledge of data structures directly informs database design, caching strategies, and query optimization. The same principles apply at different scales.

questions.question: What's the industry equivalent of OOP principles?
options: Industry abandoned OOP for functional programming
System architecture: services, APIs, and contracts
OOP is the same in industry
There is no equivalent
questions.explanation: Encapsulation and inheritance scale up to microservices and API contracts. A service is just encapsulation at the network level‚Äîthe patterns transfer directly!

questions.question: Why does Big-O analysis still matter in industry?
options: It doesn't‚Äîwe have fast computers now
Only for interview prep
It guides performance optimization and scaling decisions
It's required for code reviews
questions.explanation: When your code runs millions of times, algorithmic complexity determines if your system scales or crashes. Big-O analysis is crucial for production performance work.

questions.question: Why is now the 'perfect time' to enter the industry?
options: Job market is great
AI tools let new grads work at a higher level immediately
Salaries are at all-time highs
Remote work is more common
questions.explanation: AI tools give new grads capabilities that took previous generations years to develop. You can understand codebases faster, generate code, and learn continuously.

questions.question: How should you use AI when joining a new team?
options: Ask AI to do all your work
Avoid AI to prove your skills
Use AI to understand the codebase before asking teammates
Only use AI for writing tests
questions.explanation: Use AI to explore and understand the codebase first. You'll ramp up faster, ask smarter questions when you do need help, and impress with your initiative.

questions.question: What's your ultimate competitive advantage?
options: Just AI skills
Just CS fundamentals
CS fundamentals combined with AI execution speed
Working longer hours
questions.explanation: Your CS fundamentals help you understand why things work. AI helps you execute at speed. Together, they make you formidable‚Äîunderstanding AND velocity.
